definition: to support by the arm/to help/to promote/at the side/also pr. [yi4]
to tuck (into a pocket)/to hide/to conceal
"hand" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 64), occurring in 提, 把, 打 etc
Zhangye prefecture level city in Gansu
Zhangye prefecture level city in Gansu
to try to cover up/hiding place
Zhangye prefecture, Gansu (old term)/Zhangye prefecture level city 張掖市|张掖市[Zhang1 ye4 shi4] (district in Gansu)
to recommend sb for a promotion/to guide and support sb
Lateral Courts in the imperial palace (housing concubines and administrative offices

sentences.english: Keep them informative yet concise . People want information quickly, and withholding it only annoys them.
sentences.chinese: 人們希望迅速獲得信息，藏着掖着只會惹惱他們。

sentences.english: Mother slipped into the room of her child and tucked him up.
sentences.chinese: 媽媽悄悄進了孩子的房間給他掖好被子。

sentences.english: The lecturer walked in with a file under his arm.
sentences.chinese: 演講者掖下夾着一個文件走了進來。

sentences.english: He had tucked her in comfortably.
sentences.chinese: 他幫她把披肩掖得更舒服了一些。

sentences.english: Tuck in your shirt; it looks awful hanging out of your pants.
sentences.chinese: 把你的襯衣掖進去，垂在長褲外面很不好。

sentences.english: I left the children tucked up snugly in bed.
sentences.chinese: 我給孩子們掖好被子，讓他們睡覺了。

definition: (to move or do sth) softly and quietly (idiom)
to push aside (clothing, curtain etc) to reveal something/to toss aside
the front piece(s) of a Chinese jacket/lapel
to gather together/to collect/to approach/to draw near to/to add/to sum up/to comb (hair)
to draw towards oneself/to gather/to gather up (one's gown, sleeves etc)/to grab (money)/to extort
to hug/to embrace/to hold in one's arms
